climbs.name: Getting Oriented
climbs.fa: M. Wilford, S. Parent, C. French, M. Hrubant, R. Page. March, 1991

content.description: Moderate classic at Kama Bay. Incredible climb. Can be done in either one or two (60m ropes required) pitches. The route consists of roughly two sections separated by a bowl/ledge in the middle. The first section can either be climbed diagonally up via the ramp system to the left (WI3+) or straight up (WI4+). From the bowl the ice steepens and checks in as WI4/4+ to the top. The route is easily recognizable from the distance by the characteristic large daggers. It is the first large ice formation that can be seen to the right as one drives along Domtar 81 road. The approach trail starts to the right of "Crown Land" sign (see beta Getting Oriented and PG-13 as seen from the Domtar 81 Road. The access trail starts to the right of the Crown Land sign. ) directly below the route. The trail through the woods is well marked by orange ribbons. Two rock bands on the approach are equipped with fixed ropes. Ice screws. Slings for the rappel.

climbs.name: Leap Year
climbs.fa: Matt Giambrone, Donnie Kolb, James Loveridge, Guy Lacelle

content.description:
Straightforward ice climbing leads to a large ice ledge at half height, and the beginning of the mixed climbing. Follow the obvious seams up the overhanging wall to gain the upper ice.  The difficulty of the route will, I believe, vary from about M7 to M8+ with the volume of ice on the upper section.  The gear is quite good although it may be strenuous to place

This route is around the corner to the right of Getting Oriented, and is located on the left hand wall of the large cleft that houses the route PG-13.  Descend from the anchors for PG-13 or Getting Oriented.
A standard mixed rack including several pins and a handful of screws should do the job.

Climb initial steep bulges to the comfortable ledge where you can stand and de-pump. From here commit to the vertical crux section (WI5/5+ - depending on conditions). The route is located around the buttress to the right of Getting Oriented (see beta photos Kama Bay, Ontario. Getting Oriented (left) and PG-13 (right). View from the base. 16 March '09. and Getting Oriented and PG-13 as seen from the Domtar 81 Road. The access trail starts to the right of the Crown Land sign. ). Approach is the same as for Getting Oriented. We only needed ice screws although "Ice Climbs of the Lake Superior Region" mentions that rock gear may be needed in lean conditions.

An amazing pillar of ice that rarely forms.  The route shares the initial ice of Getting Oriented before climbing an obvious freestanding pillar to the left.  The pillar was fractured across nearly its entire width just below the point where it joins the rock so climb with care.   
  
 On the first ascent, the pillar wasn't completely formed so it was climbed up the right side and gear was more difficult.  Later in the season the best line was was steep, sustained climbing right up the front on great ice.  The fracture remained a feature of the climb the entire season!  Spooky! 

The start is the same as for Getting Oriented.  Rappel of a tree at the top.
Screws.  As many as you care to put in.

pathTokens: LAKE SUPERIOR W: Marathon to Thunder Bay, includes Kama and Orient Bay
Kama Bay, Lake Superior, Ice and Mixed

content.description: Getting Oriented was one of the first routes to be done in Kama Bay and it is home to several more now-classic routes.
